Many languages don’t have the sound th. Just by looking at it, you would think it’s a t with a silent h. But the sound is a soft, slightly aspirated s sound with the tongue touching the lower part of the upper front teeth.

Especially Germans get a lot of laughs from native speakers for their lacking of th. It sounds more like a z. That’s why they are often called tongue in cheek Zee Germans.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYdIXRTBXLo

 

One way to exercise is to stick out your tongue and attempt to make an S sound. This will probably look ridiculous, but it prevents your tongue to go all the way up to the roof of the mouth. The th sound will be created. Once you recognize the sound, you can practice on replicating it without accidentally spitting on everyone in front of you.

Now you can say with confidence:

they thought the title needed some thorough thought.

This project is maintained by Steve Smith
